8/8 The decentralization of banking is here. It just hasn’t been evenly distributed yet. Read more: https://t.co/Et36l3UOW1
7/8 Operating locally has killed the banks’ abilities to join more open global web of financial services, except via onramps and offramps.
6/8 Suddenly, your traditional bank account will look like no more than a node on the global cloud of financial networks.
5/8 We already have powerful global networks that are seamless across boundaries, and we are complementing the reach of those new networks.
4/8 Your bank account becomes a back-end, as you manipulate money via smartphones, Apps, cryptocurrency accounts, or web services directly.
3/8 The banks alone would not allow us to accomplish what these linkages enable, which is why we have to go through these intermediaries.
2/8 Link your bank account to Eventbrite, a Bitcoin exchange, Kickstarter, PayPal, ApplePay, Venmo, and you can do some interesting things.
1/8 The more we link our bank accounts to external services and apps, the more we are living in a world of decentralized banking.

14/14 The blockchain is destined to become the new website. Read More: https://t.co/2AvWZqjG5g
13/14 Advice: Pair a technical person with a business manager: magical moments happen when business and technology understand each other.
12/14 Advice: Acquire knowledge internally. Don’t outsource it, because you would be outsourcing experience you need to gain directly.
11/14 Things to learn: writing smart contracts, creating or tokenizing assets, interacting with blockchain APIs, programming a blockchain.
10/14 Moving assets, identities, ownerships, contracts, balances, records, data on the blockchain is 1st phase like 1st websites in 90’s.
9/14 That would create a large inventory of tradeable blockchain assets, and a resulting groundswell of economic activity.
8/14 Imagine if any real world asset could be mirrored on the blockchain directly (creation/transfer), or indirectly (anchoring).
7/14 Think about other familiar asset classes that can mimic Bitcoin’s capabilities, and you can start to imagine some of the possibilities.
6/14 Bitcoin as cryptocurrency is quintessential digital asset & moves efficiently & transparently across global blockchain w no boundaries.
5/14 With blockchain, asset ownership is with owner of the asset, not with a (central) party who owns a database that points to the owner.
4/14 Exchanging anything we own, and challenging existing trusted authorities and custodians that held the keys to accessing our assets.
3/14 "Decentralization of Trust" enables new "value flow without intermediaries", unleashes new opportunities.
2/14 5 phases of Internet: Personal Communications, Self-Publishing, E-Commerce, Social Web, Trust-based Services.
1/14 Every company will have a blockchain, or be on a blockchain or several, just as organizations are involved in many websites today.

11/11 Read more on Maximizing User Adoption by Understanding Behavioral Economics for Startups https://t.co/WJDE5Ipfdy
10/11 Find your risk seeking segments of users (and there could be several of them), and you will get easier adoptions for your product.
9/11 Understanding prospect theory is critical in finding your initial target segments, so you don’t spin your wheels with the wrong ones.
8/11 On your website & communications, highlight loss words & remind prospects wht they are “missing out” v. wht they could be gaining.
7/11 Break-up the different parts of your product & ask yourself: is this feature in the domain of risk aversion or risk seeking?
6/11 Risk averse prospects are happy with their current situation and will push-back on your pitches and trials.
5/11 Startups need to go after a segment of prospects that are risk-seekers: currently with no solution, or incurring losses.
4/11 People strongly prefer avoiding losses to acquiring gains. Losses are twice as powerful as gains for moving people from status quo.
3/11 People make decisions based on the potential value of losses and gains rather than the final outcome.
2/11 Prospect theory is behavioral economic theory describing how people choose b/w alternatives that involve risk, with known outcomes.
1/11 It's important to understand that “People tend to be risk-seeking in the domain of losses and risk-averse in the domain of gains”.

10/10 Read more, Is the Blockchain an Alphabet Soup or a Full-Stack? - https://t.co/auFINAhR1m
9/10 There is case for blockchain based on a-la-carte alphabet soup menu but there is also case for more benefits from full-stack adherence.
8/10 The more stack layers you remove, the more need to be realistic about benefits expectations derived from a blockchain adoption.
7/10 The more pure, the more benefits in terms of innovation, disruption and reengineering potential.
6/10 How much functionality you remove is a consideration when assessing the potential benefits one can derive from that blockchain.
5/10 List of variations is long: blockchain no Btc, Btc no keys, ledgers no mining, consensus no Btc, ledgers no tokens or no mining, etc.
4/10 Are we at the dawn of a new alphabet soup of technologies, or a fully organized stack? And what is the better approach?
3/10 While seeing various degrees of implementations, need to understand what we give-up when pieces of the “stack” intentionally missing.
2/10 Need to understand various nuances in benefits and drawbacks of having a “full-stack” blockchain versus “non full-stack” one.
1/10 Blockchain maximalism takes a purist view and follows a Blockchain “full-stack” approach, advocating it’s an all-or-none situation.

9/9 Read more, The Networks They Are A-Changin' - http://t.co/KL27fdQoiK
8/9 Protocols have relationships with underlying networks, but they in turn create other networks on top, based on the protocol itself.
7/9 Decentralized protocols facilitate P2P relationships between autonomous entities. Protocols embed complexity but imbue simplicity.
6/9 New Protocols enable New Networks that create new companies who threaten incumbents.
5/9 A new breed of decentralized applications, called DApps will run smart consensus logic on the blockchain’s virtual machine code.
4/9 P2P commerce opens an untapped global market for e-trade that touches people who didn’t partake in 1st wave of centralized e-commerce.
3/9 Money movements & trading can operate on blockchain-enabled networks, more openly, and more “swiftly” than on existing global networks.
2/9 Decentralization is a meta-theme that is enabling a number of big changes: Decentralization of Money, Trade and Software Applications.
1/9 Tweetstorm: New Networks + New Protocols + Decentralization = New Companies that threaten incumbents.

9/9 Read more: Revisiting Mentorship: Diversify your Mentors as you Grow your Startup http://t.co/SwQxvDNdOq
8/9 Your needs are changing, so why not change who you are being surrounding with and influenced by?
7/9 Think about re-evaluating your mentors, role models and advisors at every successive funding round or stage of growth that you reach.
6/9 Lesson: Aim high & try to go out-of-the-box when it comes to mentoring support.
5/9 Case: @BChesky expanded his mentorship horizons & went high by picking legendary role models for specific mentorship & learning advice.
4/9 Therefore, the type of mentoring required becomes more prescriptive & less suggestive because situations & issues have more clarity.
3/9 As a startup finds product/market fit, there decreasing ambiguity about their business & they need less ambiguous mentoring & support.
2/9 A diversity in mentorship is good for early stage startups, but as a startup grows, I suggest they should recycle their mentors.
1/9 Tweetstormed thoughts on Startups Mentorship evolution.

10/10 Read more from my post http://t.co/O2AdboVvBf
9/10 No one else but the CEO can be the standard bearer for their brand. Don’t let it be your blindspot.
8/10 “Brand” is that blindspot that startup CEO’s have if they don't value its importance. Brand pulls you forward and helps you grow.
7/10 It is not unusual to see Product & Culture on the list of other startup CEO’s priorities. But it is less likely to see Brand on it.
6/10 Although peer groups are great, you won’t learn what your peers haven’t yet experienced.
5/10 Brian Chesky decided to take his mentorship up, not sideways.
4/10 Brian Chesky self-educated himself at age 33, as a first-time CEO, as he became obsessed with figuring how what he needed to learn.
3/10 I’ve been critical of startup CEO’s who don't recognize that elevating their company’s brand is their job, not the marketing dept’s.
2/10 I was heartened to learn that @BChesky, one of my favorite startup CEO’s (@airbnb) has 3 key priorities: Product, Brand, Culture.
1/10 "The Biggest Blindspot of a Startup CEO is Ignoring Their Brand"

1/13 Beyond an amazing product, nimble engineering & a great team, marketing excellence is the next big differentiation factor for startups.
2/13 Typical marketing books were mostly written during the era of large company marketing, and focused on established brands.
3/13 Today, “digital marketing” has overshadowed our activities and understanding of marketing practices.
4/13 But marketing has 2 sides: a quantitative/measurable one & a non-quantitative one.
5/13 Non-quantitative marketing (Branding) appeals to the mind, perceptions, expectations, experiences, feelings and emotions of the market.
6/13 The Branding side of marketing is the most difficult to understand by a startup CEO.
7/13 What is your single most powerful differentiator, the one idea that you should be identified with?
8/13 What is that one promise that you must make and keep to build your business?
9/13 Marketing is telling your message very clearly and simply to a segment of the market who has never heard about you.
10/13 Branding is how your prospects think about you before they experience your product.
11/13 Startups who don’t focus pro-actively on building their brand are making it harder to command a higher valuation.
12/13 As much as users and engagement contributed to your early valuation, brand and its strength are an amplifier of your market value.
13/13 Read the Blog Post Why a Strong Brand Means Higher Growth and Better Valuation for your Startup http://t.co/nTOg2XH31I

1/13 Thoughts on Bitcoin, Blockchains, Distributed Ledgers, Ethereum & Cryptocurrency in Financial Services, from my recent post.
2/13 The blockchain will not make most impact where it is adopted early, but where change is hardest to achieve, and that might take longer.
3/13 Will banks fail to reinvent themselves as they did with Internet, or will they induce a self-inflicted shake-up and embrace the future?
4/13 If you use “blockchains without Bitcoin” just to avoid public blockchains, you will be subjected to a huge market blind spot. Do both.
5/13 If financial services were re-invented today from scratch, we would be OK with virtual, online, Internet & blockchain-enabled services.
6/13 Don’t just do pilots that automate old processes. Rather, launch major reengineering efforts across all processes.
7/13 Ask the important question: What could Crypto-Tech enable now if we reinvented it?
8/13 Hire or promote a real leader from within, and give them the title of “Blockchain Czar".
9/13 Buy a Bitcoin Exchange. One of the big banks will blink first & buy one of the 50 Bitcoin exchanges and delight their customers.
10/13 When every asset has a blockchain linkage, it puts it at par with bits that travel at Internet speeds.
11/13 The blockchain is not perfect, but it is a perfect catalyst for reengineering, and this opportunity doesn’t present itself that often.
12/13 Banks can go slow and be left behind, or they can go deep and leapfrog.

9/9 More in the blog post - Communicating your Vision vs. Communicating your Product http://t.co/IDEYqCwyId
8/9 And keep the vision for the VC pitches. Let it unravel on its own to the market.
7/9 Don’t introduce your vision to the marketplace. Introduce your product rather.
6/9 Visions are generally fuzzy, and they aren’t believable initially. They only get clearer as your market footprint increases.
5/9 Users don’t really care whether you achieve your vision or not (or what it is). They are lured by how compelling your product is.
4/9 If you have a great vision, think about how your users can boot-up your vision. That bootup starts with the product, not vision.
3/9 Don’t introduce your vision to the market if it’s too hard to see the linkage between that vision and what the product does for users.
2/9 Mistake is to blurt out your vision on the marketplace instead of communicating a user behavior you want to induce.
1/9 Communicating your Vision vs. Communicating your Product: Which comes first, and how to differentiate? Some key points from my post.

1/9 The fragmented aspects of the Internet are becoming almost unmanageable at the content and services levels for end-user applications.
2/9 Every time a new service is created with marginal benefits, it adds a layer of complexity and potential distraction.
3/9 When we add something, if something else is not removed, we increasing our attention deficit because we are bloating the system.
4/9 Choice is OK, when it's differentiated. If not, confusion & distraction drown us, as we hardly see clarity in marginal differentiation.
5/9 Just because a new service or product is available doesn’t mean that its value is clear.
6/9 When products aren’t so perfect, more expensive than others, how you market them and communicate their value becomes really important.
7/9 Dumbing things down to explain what you are doing is important to get a VC’s attention, but it’s not enough for the long term.
8/9 You need to follow through by differentiating yourself and by resonating with the emotions and needs of your users and customers.

1/10 Speaking of tech ecosystems, no ecosystem in the world is perfect, including the one in Silicon Valley.
2/10 But SV is the only region that's been producing industry giants for each wave of technological innovation cycles, decade after decade.
3/10 Pre 80’s, Semiconductors and Aerospace: Intel, Fairchild, Lockheed Martin, Hewlett-Packard.
4/10 80′s, Computers and Software: Sun Microsystems, Oracle, HP, Apple.
5/10 90′s, Networking and Internet I: Netscape, Cisco, Yahoo!, eBay.
6/10 2000′s: Internet II and Cloud Computing: Google, Apple 2.0, Salesforce, Netflix, VMware.
7/10 2010’s: Social and Tech Energy: Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, UBER, Dropbox, Tesla, SolarCity.
8/10 What sets an ecosystem apart is not the degree in which it tries to copy Silicon Valley, but in how it develops its own uniqueness.
9/10 You don’t need a perfect ecosystem, but you need many of your ecosystem parts to be excellent.
10/10 Focus on making the parts excellent, and a great ecosystem will emerge. Read more: http://t.co/7tYnsovgrU

1/15 We need to understand how new value will be created on the blockchain and via cryptocurrency-related businesses.
2/15 What is the purpose of money? The purpose of money is to enable paying for something that has a value attached to it.
3/15 The “payment” part is going to be challenged by cryptocurrency, because “paying” and “receiving” are now being bundled together.
4/15 Value is more important than money. Yes, money is value, but not all value is money, especially as amplified on the blockchain.
5/15 Money enabled value exchange, but the blockchain is about value transfer, and it's about transferring something different than money.
6/15 Value is represented by what it unlocks at the end of the transaction, not by what gets deposited for later usage.
7/15 Cryptocurrency provides an equivalent way to paying for things, but without actually paying for them with traditional currency.
8/15 Accounting for revenues will get muddled with receiving a “right” instead of seeing actual fiat revenues.
9/15 This will create new movement options for value creation, beyond what traditional currencies enable.
10/15 What the blockchain enables is a new “flow of value”, a concept related to economics Nobel laureate Michael Spence’s work.
11/15 The blockchain is a new digital value leveler as it impacts and shifts value within the cryptospace and into our physical spaces.
12/15 The blockchain moves the power of transactions closer to the individuals & it merges (crypto) capital & labor with mobile markets.
13/15 We are in the early stages of understanding the movement, distribution and creation of “value” outside of the traditional norms.
14/15 Fiat currency and traditional property may no longer be the only vehicles for value transfers and value appreciation.
15/15 Read more "Value Creation and Movement with the Blockchain: The Easy, Difficult and Mysterious" - http://t.co/xTsRUx4aXO

1/10 For a startup, high user growth doesn’t equal high market awareness or valuation.
2/10 You need to grow your brand in the eyes of the market, specifically targeting the market that you haven’t reached yet.
3/10 Therefore, you should never be content with viral growth, organic growth, referral growth, or any type of quantitative growth.
4/10 If your mindshare isn’t at least 100X your market share, you are leaving a lot of your valuation premium potential on the table.
5/10 A “top startup” is like a “top restaurant”. Their mindshare must be everywhere there’s a potential customer that fancies trying them.
6/10 So, stop looking at what’s under your nose and start looking out the window.
7/10 Create a narrative that captures the market’s imagination and let others write about you openly, without assistance.
8/10 Virality is good for starting, but not for leaping into the great company you want to become.
9/10 The first messages you gave your early customers may not the same ones that will let you capture your next big market.
10/10 In a nutshell, "Focus Your Startup Marketing on the Mind, not the Product" Read more http://t.co/dHy7muy3jj

1/11 With Decentralization, Where is the Money? - Tweetstorm synopsis of my post http://t.co/iuuESgFqwn
2/11 If we are to strictly follow Bitcoin’s first principles of decentralization, very little to no money should be made by the centers.
3/11 Before, nothing happened without central authorities, or central powers, or central regulations, or central approvals.
4/11 With decentralization, it’s the opposite. Everything happens at the edges, and at the nodes near the peripheries of the network.
5/11 With decentralization, you don’t install a center first. You install a platform that enables the network & nodes at its periphery.
6/11 It’s not easy to become decentralized. The challenge becomes: where is the monetization behind decentralized models?
7/11 The concept of “central operations” is shattered, because maybe it doesn't exist.
8/11 The underlying protocol enables decentralized operations, and that is where the activity and value should reside.
9/11 We are still experimenting with business, revenue & value appreciation models behind decentralized networks, markets & organizations.
10/11 One thing is sure: the centers and operators should make less, and the collective of users/stakeholders/participants will make more.
11/11 Full post "With Decentralization, Where is the Money?" http://t.co/iuuESgFqwn

1/8 Rant re: paying for mediocre reports from research analysts.
2/8 I prefer informed/experienced opinion with some analysis, than lots of analysis with meaningless opinion.
3/8 I think Research is the next field that's going free on the internet, like content. Wait a minute, it is free. Just Google anything.
4/8 People with more money than brains would pay $4K for a "Bitcoin market report" when they can use Google or buy 2 books at $11 each.
5/8 There is little intellectual honesty anymore in research. You're probing Peter to rob Paul.
6/8 Most 5 year predictions about the Internet were wrong during 1995-1999. No one can tell what will happen in 6 months in crypto-land!
7/8 If anyone says they know exactly what will happen with Bitcoin / Blockchain / Cryptocurrency; they are hyping, speculating or lying.
8/8 There is lots of work ahead, and we should stay heads-down & focused on producing products and technology that people will benefit from.

1/9 An Operational Framework for Decentralized Autonomous Organizations - quick bites from my post http://t.co/CWijKOmglb
2/9 The concept of a “Distributed Autonomous Organization/Corporation” is an idealistic outcome of the crypto-tech revolution.
3/9 So how do you get there, and what are the pieces of the puzzle from an operational / practical view?
4/9 Just adding crypto-tech doesn’t make the DAO successful. A DAO is DOA (dead on arrival) until the market validates its assumptions.
5/9 An operational framework for a DAO needs to tackle 6 functional areas: Scope, Stake, Value, Governance, Gains, and Technology.
6/9 A Key objective of a DAO is value creation or production.
7/9 There needs to be a specific linkage between user actions and the effects of those actions on the overall value to the organization.
9/9 If you thought that spinning a DAO is a walk in the park, it won’t be. Full post: http://t.co/CWijKOmglb
8/9 A new DAO is like a startup. It requires a product/market fit, business model realization and a lot of users/customers.

1/13 How the Crytoconomy Will be Created. Summary of my op-ed in Forbes.
2/13 What Bitcoin started is turning into something bigger: a “crypto-tech” economy with its own value creation.
3/13 This cryptoconomy will not happen by attacking the current financial system, nor by fiat money transfers into cryptocurrency wallets.
4/13 Rather it will emerge by creating its own wealth, via new types of services and businesses that extend beyond money transactions.
5/13 The cryptoconomy is about the next phase of the Internet’s evolution – the decentralization era.
6/13 Just as we had Web businesses, we will have crypto-tech businesses. They are being defined now along 4 segments:
7/13 a. Services where trust component is stored on the blockchain. b. Services where contractual component is executed on the blockchain.
8/13 c. Decentralized peer-to-peer marketplaces. d. Distributed Autonomous Organizations (DAOs).
9/13 Undoubtedly this looks fuzzy, foggy, risky, buggy, uncertain and unproven, but so did the Internet in 1995.
10/13 The blockchain symbolizes a shift in power from the centers to the edges of the networks.
11/13 Existing intermediaries are at risk. New ones will be virtual, transparent, distributed entities that are trusted programmatically.
12/13 The cryptoconomy will transfigure businesses, government and society, perhaps more profoundly than the Internet did, 20 years ago.
13/13 This cryptoconomy will unravel and blossom over the next 10 years. Read more: http://t.co/z4znSRhD9B

1/17 I wonder if the TCP/IP analogy can be equated to bitcoin the protocol & what the Network Effects are for the cryptocurrency ecosystem?
2/17 If TCP/IP is like bitcoin the protocol, Bitcoin users are 2 steps removed from it, just as web users are steps removed from TCP/IP.
3/17 Actually, network routers talk to TCP/IP, not users directly, just as Bitcoin users don’t talk to the bitcoin protocol directly.
4/17 TCP/IP was needed to facilitate Internet access, for the network pieces to look like one & allow any computer to connect to it.
5/17 Def. "TCP/IP provides end-to-end connectivity specifying how data should be packetized, addressed, transmitted, routed & received."
6/17 What is “data” in the cryptocurrency context? It’s the value that’s encrypted and stored in the blockchain.
7/17 Arguably, Blockchains are the transport mules for cryptographic data, and the lowest level building block for cryptocurrency apps.
8/17 Blockchain is a new beast: a mixture of a database, a data bus, a storage place, a transport container, part public & part private.
9/17 A Blockchain talks to computer programs, exchanges, wallets, browsers, other blockchains and services on top of that.
10/17 Why use old constructs on something new before it develops? That brings us to the topic of Bitcoin/Blockchain Network Effects.
11/17 Arguably, network effects are more useful at the App level, as we take them for granted at the Network level.
12/17 Yes, Bitcoin has already a large network of users with cryptocurrency wallets, but active usage has been low.
13/17 Currency usage has stalled while we are waiting for blockchain apps to emerge. Maybe the currency app isn’t its killer app.
14/17 Yes, owning Btc currency makes it easier to on-board a cryptocurrency App, but perhaps there will there be other ways to on-board.
15/17 Yes, we see lots of development on the Bitcoin blockchain and its Btc currency, but there is also lots of activity off-Bitcoin.
16/17 Do we need network effects on Bitcoin only, or on generic Blockchain Apps whether they are Btc based or not?
17/17 I’m sure that question will be answered over the course of 2015. #EOTS

1/9 Let’s roll back judgment on Bitcoin and the blockchain network effects. It's too early to tell.
2/9 The romantic notion that a very large network of Bitcoin users would vindicate the case for a single blockchain backbone is a stretch.
3/9 We need to think more in terms of blockchain apps, and less in terms of Bitcoin users.
4/9 The Bitcoin network doesn’t need to replace the Internet, because the Internet is that global network.
5/9 All Bitcoin (or any blockchain) has to do is overlay itself on the Internet & achieve network effects on its own merits & services.
6/9 Best to keep Bitcoin (or any blockchain) as thin platforms and not bloat them excessively & let them enable many use cases on top.
7/9 Yes, Bitcoin is programmable money, but blockchain is also programmable value, programmable governance, programmable assets, etc.
8/9 Let’s not forget the basic golden rule of network effects: without users, there is no network effect.
9/9 End of tweet storm. Read full post here http://t.co/zXJz7CAc4G

1/11 I'm seeing two red flags relating to venture capital in Bitcoin related tech startups.
2/11 We have Bitcoin "experts & pioneers" investing in Bitcoin companies, but they are venture capital newbies.
3/11 And I'm seeing some experienced VCs as newbies in the Bitcoin space, but they aren't taking the time to really understanding it well.
4/11 In the 1st case, they add little value or contribute mildly to a startup's growth. Many of these experts have never built companies.
5/11 The 2nd case will result in bad investments, just as the 1st case will result in bad startups.
6/11 Smart crypto/bitcoin startups, with smart & knowledgeable investors are still few. I'm issuing this warning based on what I'm seeing.
7/11 VCs that want to invest in crypto really need to immerse themselves with firsthand knowledge about this space.
8/11 Just as Bitcoin experts-turned investors need to surround themselves with seasoned VCs and learn from them.
9/11 I'm not sure if this is a passage we are going through, or an ailment we will suffer from.
10/11 If it's a passage, we will emerge stronger. If ailment, it will not help Bitcoin's much needed emancipation.
11/11 Thoughts and responses welcome from @pmarca @fredwilson @cdixon @howardlindzon @balajis

1/10 Why Bitcoin's Price is Irrelevant to its Success...Tweetstorming a summary of my post.
2/10 The last thing Bitcoin needed was a continued frenzy into higher valuations.
3/10 Bitcoin’s price had been growing beyond its promised expectations to deliver something useful to the masses.
4/10 There are really two basic things that Bitcoin needs to do: 1) put more bitcoin with users, 2) get users to USE it.
5/10 Why should Bitcoin’s price be so high while Bitcoin-enabled services have yet to come to life?
6/10 Lower Btc prices give developers room to breathe & give consumers a chance to taste the Bitcoin magic without forking a fortune.
7/10 I think we are entering a new chapter in the evolution of Bitcoin, where its price doesn’t matter, but rather its capabilities do.
8/10 Bitcoin narrative needs to change. Need less headlines about Bitcoin’s price, and more on Bitcoin-based innovations and applications.
9/10 Let’s hope this Bitcoin crash is a wake-up call. It has hurt a few people, but it’s going to benefit a lot more in the long term.
10/10 My full post is here: http://t.co/UNqd16aV7Q

1/6 Close to releasing a long post (2,700 words) on the Practice of Startup Management, a summary for a book I was going to write last year.
2/6 Here's a teaser. Everything can be summed-up in 3 tenets of startup management. They are:
3/6 STRUCTURING right. How do you right-size your organizational structure for each successive stage of evolution?
4/6 being COMPETITIVE. How do you compete vigorously across all elements of a sustainable competitive advantage spectrum?
5/6 MANAGING well. How do you manage your people and teams well, so they can perform effectively to help you reach your objectives?
6/6 So ask yourself 3 Q's: Do I have the right organizational structure? Am I competing vigorously Am I managing the people and company?

1/10 Today, e-book publishers matter more than traditional book publishers.
2/10 New/emerging authors don’t matter too much to traditional publishers, because their old processes aren’t oriented towards them.
3/10 First, They’ll offer you a very low advance. Second, they take forever to “accept your proposal”.
4/10 Third, they really expect you to do your own marketing by hiring a PR agency or figuring out your own media promotion.
5/10 Fourth, they’ll assign an editor to your project who knows nothing about your topic. Fifth, there's a long publishing schedule.
6/10 Sixth, your book’s distribution plan will be at the whims of their relationships with bookstores.
7/10 Seventh, anything online is an after-thought, and not really a focus. There is more, but I'll stop there.
8/10 Today, the economics of book publishing favor the online world, not because the costs of printing a book are removed...
9/10 ...but bc costs of promotion and distribution are much lower. Costs of printing are small compared to costs of marketing and awareness.
10/10 Read about my love/hate relationship with publishers on the @fgpress blog,- Do Publishers Matters? http://t.co/wReiOSZY9G

I just did an experiment. Wrote a blog post, then chopped its intro as a Tweetstorm & linked to it in last tweet. @pmarca @fredwilson
1/7 There is an “Internet user stack” that guides our digital lives, as consumers of Internet technology.
2/7 In '94, all you needed was a browser to access websites, and an email to reach people. That was the user stack then.
3/7 And it stayed that way for a good 10 years, until the Social Web arrived in 2004 and got us into sharing and self-expression.
4/7 Fast forward to 2014, email, browsing and being social are table stakes, and hardly give a real advantage to any Internet user.
5/7 Today, the user stack of the past 20 years is about to become much more complicated, because the bar is raised on being digitally savvy.
6/7 I see 5 new "user stack" areas: Consumer Cloud, Self-Quantification, Smartification of Things, Cryptocurrency, and Personal Robotics.

1/6 How do you define Decentralization?
2/6 If Centers are the opposite of Networks, is Network Effect the opposite of Central Control?
3/6 The role of the center is being re-defined. The center controls less, but it facilitates more.
4/6 Control is eroding central organizations, in favor of edge power. Old centers are getting unbundled.
5/6 The “network attacks itself” – its central pieces are getting de-fragmented and re-purposed autonomously.
6/6 Those who master the art of balancing centers and network functions will win.
